awd_titl_txt: Gordon Research Conference: Membranes: Materials and Processes 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
Critical societal needs in the areas of energy, water, bioprocessing, and the environment are providing exciting new opportunities for membrane technologies. These include the development of new membranes for fuel cells, water purification, the production of biofuels, and the isolation of a target molecule from a complex chemical mixture. Over the past 20 years, there has been a growing understanding of how molecular scale phenomena at the membrane interface translate to systems-level engineering design and optimization. This project will support young research investigators to travel to the 2018 Gordon Research Conference and  associated Gordon Research Seminar: Membranes Materials and Processes held at Colby Sawyer College in New London, NH from August 11-12 and 12-17, 2018.

The theme of this conference is focused on all aspects of membrane science, with specific sessions on molecules, membranes and membrane systems and their application to contemporary topics dealing with energy production and storage, membrane technologies for energy efficiency, nanomanufacturing, and membranes for water purification. A number of speakers have been invited from a variety of disciplines including: Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Environmental Engineering, Chemistry, Physics, Biology, Nanoscience, and Material Science. The discussions between the speakers and audience will provide valuable feedback on current research efforts and will enable the participants to further develop and refine new ideas for their own research and/or to initiate new membrane projects. This 5-day technical conference provides a unique forum for discussion of cutting edge research in membrane science and technology. A student seminar precedes the conference, providing mentoring and networking opportunities for young researchers.  This grant will provide registration support for US-based undergraduate students, graduate students, and young postdoctoral research associates to attend the conference. It is anticipated that the registration of 50 students will be partially supported.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Membrane processes have become ubiquitous in process industries, water and wastewater purification, and even in daily life. The science and engineering relevant to membrane processes span length scales from the molecular scale (angstroms to nm) to the module scale (meters) and further to large acre-scale systems that can process millions of kilograms of materials per day. Catalyzed by broad interest across a wide range of disciplines, innovations are occurring daily at each of these scales. The goal of the Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Membranes: Materials and Processes, Translating Molecular Scale Discoveries to Commercial-Scale Membrane Operations, was to provide the attendees both a snapshot of some of these advances as well as the opportunity to engage in active discussions regarding the fundamental principles behind new advances, the ever-evolving understanding of transport in and structure of membranes at the molecular scale, and the challenges and opportunities for translating some of these exciting advances to practical scales.

A Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) was held prior to the GRC.  The two-day seminar is designed specifically for graduate students, post-doctoral students, and other scientists with comparable levels of experience. At these seminars, which take place immediately prior to the associated GRC, young investigators present and discuss cutting-edge, unpublished research and build collaborative relationships with colleagues and peers in a non-intimidating environment. GRSs are particularly important, however, because they allow the next generation of scientists to network and discuss their research at a critical time in their careers. Ninety-five percent of GRS participants continue on and attend the associated Gordon Research Conference.  The Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Membranes: Materials and Processes, From Molecules to Modules: A Journey from Molecular Designs of Membranes to High-Performance Membrane Modules, was held prior to the GRC and presented the state of the art of current membrane materials and modules for a variety of applications, including liquid, gas and bioprocessing separations. In the focus were discussions on how to improve membrane performances based on molecular designs of membrane materials and how the design and development of modules integrate high performances from molecular engineering into scale-up applications. The seminar included a variety of interesting talks and poster presentations, with plenty of room for discussions about membrane science and technology. Finally, the seminar invited academic and industry mentors to share their experiences of working in the membrane society. The seminar was a great platform for all students and postdocs to present their research and enjoy the networking before joining the GRC.

 

This award specifically helped support the registration of 30 student and postdoctoral attendees to the conference.
